text: Patient: All of it. Doctor: And, so you didn’t get any kind of call from the company that did the test? Patient: No. Doctor: As far as you know? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh okay. Patient: The only e-mail that I got was a confirmation that they had received my test. Family Member: But that was the only thing, right? Not that that’s a small thing, but that was – there was no other genetic, uh, information. Doctor: Actually, I gave you the wrong information. I’m sorry. So, it’s actually a higher chance that they inherit it because it’s --- I, I forgot this is what’s called – so there’s two kinds of mutations; dominant and recessive. So, recessive means you have to, uh, uh, get, uh, two bad copies to – I want to say it’s a twenty-five percent chance because you have to get two bad copies. But, in this case, if you get one bad copy, you are at risk even though you have one good copy. So, in that case, it sort of takes out your, the mother. So, they, they have a fifty percent chance of getting this gene from you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, uh, so if they get it, they’re at risk, and if they don’t get it – so, it’s a fifty-fifty as opposed to a recessive where they have a fifty percent chance from you and a fifty percent chance from the mother, and they have to get two copies to have a problem. Patient: Okay. But –

text: Family Member: or is he still gonna feel fatigued and miserable. Doctor: You should feel better. I know it’s counterintuitive. Like wait, you’re poisoning me and you’re telling me I would feel better. I think you feel bad because your cancer is not controlled, Patient: Okay. Doctor: you know, and some people could have a PSA at three thousand and feel better than you. Some people could have a PSA of thirty and feel worse than you. I don’t really care what the number is. I do know that your cancer isn’t treated. So, when you have untreated cancer you just don’t feel good. Patient: Okay, because I like to work outside and do stuff Doctor: Um hum Patient: and I do that but then it seems like the next day, does that have a part to it or no? Family Member: If he overdoes it on one day. Doctor: Oh, of course. Oh, everybody does that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Everybody does that not just you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know there’s two philosophies with that which is like oh, if it’s good day I’m gonna max it out so I can veg out the next day and I have some other patients that will just like pace themselves like I know it’s a good day but I don’t want to pay the price the next day so I’ll just moderate myself and then it’s more even. So, it’s really your preference. Some people would just be like I’d rather have one good day out of three rather than my the eh days.

text: Patient: This will be done here? Doctor: Those – a lot of those intense monitoring and everything has to be done downtown. Family Member: But is it K__ or is it H____? Doctor: K__. Gradually we can switch you back to here. Once those intense periods are done, the whatever you know close monitoring is done, then I would switch you back to coming here and getting the medication dispensed. Patient: Does is require an IV or anything like that? Doctor: It will. They’ll probably start an IV just to have it for blood draws. Family Member: But then that means they won’t prick you every time for the blood draw. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So I stay all day downtown or midtown? Family Member: And why are they, why do they, that’s interesting. Doctor: Well because they want to see how the levels of the drug, how long it takes for it to clear and things like that. So frankly along with the Xtandi there are not – this is sort of the first study of combining it with either Xtandi or Zytega and you know the single agent studies they kind of have they know what to expect. Family Member: Yeah.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: from the study standpoint. Patient: Alright, Okay. Family Member: Which is the lesser of the two evils as far as taking it long term? I’m not familiar with Cymbalta. Doctor: Well, I think Cymbalta is probably you know much more proven you know long term. The steroids can have other issues of you know blocking the immune systems likely increased risk of infections and things like that over the long term, but you know it’s – I kind of think it’s unlikely that it will help arthritic pain. If it is neuropathic nerve pain and stuff, you know Cymbalta can be effective. Patient: Yeah I think that’s what he said also yeah. Doctor: I don’t think that is the reason for your pain, but that’s my impression. Patient: Yeah, I’ll just stick with the prednisone. Doctor: Okay. And you can definitely try cutting back on the dose okay because as you saw in the scans, remember last time I had given you a slight inkling that it was heading starting to grow back? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And when we did the recent scans are showing a continued slight increase. So it’s a small increase, the bone scan is still completely okay and so you do not have the spread to the bone that we can see. Patient: Yeah, right, right. Doctor: Uh because of that I think we should stop this treatment. Okay because you’ve sort of gotten the benefit you’re going to get out of it and it may be time to move on to other treatment. Now in terms of other treatments what to go to next? And uh there is a medication that is something called Niraparib okay. And it’s sort of this family of medications called barhabiters. And the way they work is if your cancer expresses certain specific mutations, they it’s likely to be effective. So if you treat everybody with your kind of prostate cancer on this medication, the chances of it working were wherever fifty to twenty percent, so pretty low. When we looked at just the people with those mutations that were expressed in the cancer, then the response went up to seventy eighty percent. So what we’re doing…

text: Patient: And I noticed you know like the first day that Doctor: Right. Family Member: Could that trigger? Doctor: Of course. Hey my other guy, you know what he did? He wasn’t going up and down the stairs. He was just working under the tree putting his little village together. Up and down, up and down; he’s got the same symptom as you. So I think – Patient: So this isn’t something that if I give it total rest for - Doctor: Oh I’m sure that it will get better if you give it total rest. But it doesn’t change this discussion that I see new areas of cancer in your bone. Whether that’s causing pain is slightly different because I’m assuming it may. Doctor: So it isn’t like he stands there and they only shoot it up like a bone injection. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Uhn-uhn. You get an intravenous you know little catheter. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
